content.title: Penetrating Neck Trauma - Vascular Considerations
content.summary: Life-threatening injuries to cervical vessels requiring zone-based assessment and selective versus mandatory exploration based on clinical presentation and imaging findings.

definitions.definition: Zone I: clavicle to cricoid cartilage. Zone II: cricoid to angle of mandible. Zone III: angle of mandible to skull base.
Findings mandating immediate surgical exploration: active hemorrhage, expanding hematoma, pulsatile bleeding, bruit/thrill, stroke, absent pulses.
Findings warranting further evaluation: non-expanding hematoma, venous bleeding, stridor, dysphagia, hoarseness, hemoptysis, hematemesis.

key_concepts.explanation: Traditional approach: Zone I and III injuries require angiography due to difficult surgical access. Zone II injuries mandate exploration or selective management with CTA. Modern trend is toward selective management for all zones based on CTA.

Contemporary management uses CTA for all hemodynamically stable penetrating neck trauma regardless of zone. Surgical intervention is based on findings rather than zone. This reduces negative explorations while maintaining safety.

Zone I: median sternotomy or supraclavicular/trapdoor incision. Zone II: anterior SCM incision with extension. Zone III: mandibular subluxation, digastric division, styloid process removal may be required.

Primary repair preferred when possible. Interposition grafts for arterial injuries. Ligation acceptable for external carotid, internal jugular vein. Internal carotid ligation controversial - may be necessary in extremis.

evidence.finding: CTA is highly sensitive and specific for vascular injury; negative CTA safely excludes injury requiring intervention

evidence.citation: Inaba et al., WTA Multicenter Study, 2012
evidence.finding: No-zone approach with CTA reduces negative explorations without increasing missed injuries

clinical_pearls: Platysma penetration defines significant penetrating neck trauma requiring evaluation
Do not probe wounds in the emergency department - may dislodge clot
CTA of neck should include chest to evaluate Zone I and thoracic great vessels
Internal jugular vein can be ligated unilaterally without significant sequelae
Zone III injuries may benefit from endovascular techniques due to difficult surgical access
learning_objectives: Define the three zones of the neck and their boundaries
Distinguish hard from soft signs of vascular injury
Compare zone-based and no-zone approaches to penetrating neck trauma
Describe surgical exposures for each zone
State which vessels can be safely ligated
